item.title: Matrices
item.description:
1 Definition

1.1 Vector

  • A list of numbers (commonly used within the field of computer science).

  • A line segment that has both magnitude and direction (commonly used within the field of physics).

  • If it consists of only a single number, it is termed as a scalar.

1.2 Matrix

  • A rectangular array of elements (numbers or expressions).

  • It has dimensions (known also as matrix order), where is the number of rows and is the number of columns.

  • It is usually denoted by an uppercase letter.

  • It can also be also considered as an array of vectors contained in the same object.

  • Each element can be indexed by the number of its row and column (i.e., the element in the row and column is denoted by ).

  • For example, consider the following matrix :

    • .

    • is a matrix that has rows and columns.

    • The element is located in the second row and the third column.

  • If the matrix has one row (dimensions ), it is referred to as row matrix,for example: .

  • If the matrix has one column (dimensions ), it is referred to as column matrix,for example: .

  • In R, matrices can be created using the function matrix():

    Click to show/hide code 
    A <- matrix(c(2, 0, 5, 9),  # element values
            nrow = 2,       # specify the number of rows
            byrow = TRUE)   # fill the matrix by rows
A

[1,]    2    0
[2,]    5    9
    Click to show/hide code

A[2, 1]

1.3 Transpose of a matrix

  • For a matrix with dimensions , the transpose of , denoted as or , is a matrix with dimensions formed by interchanging the rows and columns of (i.e., the rows of become the columns of , and the columns of become the rows of ).

  • Example:

    • .

            nrow = 2,

[2,]    5    7    6

[2,]    8    7
[3,]    4    6

    • , where is a scalar (constant).

2 Special types of matrices

2.1 Zero matrix

  • It is a matrix having all of its elements equal to zero, for example: .

2.2 Square matrix

  • A square matrix has equal number of rows and columns (i.e., ).

  • The diagonal consists of the elements running from the top-left corner to the bottom-right corner of the matrix.

  • The trace of a square matrix is the sum of the elements of the matrix diagonal.

  • Elements other than the diagonal are termed off-diagonal.

  • Example:

    • .

    • The diagonal consists of the elements and .

    • The trace

    • The diagonal elements can be extracted from a matrix in R using the function diag():

A

[3,]    1    4   11   21
[4,]   10   17   12    8
      Click to show/hide code 
      diag(A)  # get the diagonal elements of the matrix A
      [1]  5  6 11  8

    • The trace can be calculated in R using the function trace() from the psych package:

      Click to show/hide code

tr(A)  # get the trace of the matrix A
      [1] 30

  • Symmetric and skew-symmetric square matrices:

    • If , matrix is referred to as symmetric.

    • If , matrix is referred to as skew-symmetric.

2.3 Diagonal matrix

  • It is a square matrix where all off-diagonal elements are zeros, for example:

2.4 Identity matrix

  • It is a diagonal matrix where all the diagonal elements are equal to 1, e.g., .

  • In linear algebra, the identity matrix functions like the unit scalar of 1 in ordinary scalar algebra:

    • If a square matrix with dimensions is multiplied by the identity matrix , the result is the matrix itself (i.e., ).

2.5 Invertible matrix

  • A square matrix with dimensions is invertible, if there exists another matrix with the same dimensions , such that, , where is an identity matrix with dimensions .

  • The inverse of a matrix is denoted by .

  • An invertible matrix is also referred to as non-singular matrix.

  • Invertible matrices have non-zero determinant:

    • The determinant of a matrix is a scalar value (i.e., a single numerical value) used when solving systems of linear equations or calculating the inverse of a matrix.

    • For a matrix , the determinant, denoted by or , is calculated as:

      • .

      • For example, if .

      • The determinant and the inverse of a matrix can be calculated in R using the functions det() and solve(), respectively:

    • The formulae for the determinant of matrices with dimensions greater than are complicated and are not covered here.

    • If a matrix has a determinant equal to zero, it is referred to as singular and is not invertible:

      • For example, , so matrix is singular and not invertible.

      • A singular matrix has linearly dependent rows or columns (i.e., one row or one column can be expressed as a linear combination of the others).

      • In the above example, the second row is linearly dependent on the first row (i.e., you can get the second row by multiplying the first row by ). Similarly, the second column can be obtained by multiplying the first column by .

      • A singular matrix suggests that solving a system of linear equations in the usual way is not possible.

Rank of a matrix

  • It is defined as the maximum number of linearly independent rows or columns.

  • At most, the rank can be the number of rows () or the number of columns (), so the maximum possible rank is limited by the smaller of the two dimensions and .

  • A matrix is said to have full rank if its rank is equal to the smaller of the number of rows or columns, i.e., .

  • A matrix is rank deficient if .

  • If a square matrix with dimensions is rank deficient, then it is singular and not invertible.

  • Example:

    • Rows:

      • Row is linearly dependent on row (row row ).

      • Row is identical to row , i.e, linearly dependent on it (row row ).

      • Therefore, there is only one independent row.

    • Columns:

      • Column is linearly dependent on column (column column ).

      • Column is linearly dependent on column $1$ (column colunm ).

      • Therefore, there is only one independent column.

2.7 Sparse matrix

  • It is a matrix in which most of the elements are zero (in contrast to a dense matrix, where most of the elements are non-zero).

3 Mathematical operations on matrices

3.1 Addition and subtraction

  • Matrices can be added or subtracted only if they have the same dimensions.

  • The sum or difference of two matrices and is a matrix with the same dimensions as and , where each element of is the sum or difference of the corresponding elements of and (i.e., the element of the matrix is calculated as ).

3.2 Multiplication

  • Matrices can be multiplied only if the number of columns of the first matrix is equal to the number of rows of the second matrix.

  • The product of two matrices and is a matrix with dimensions (therefore, , i.e., matrix multiplication is not commutative).

  • The element of the matrix is calculated as where is the index of the column of matrix and the row of matrix . In other words, the element is the dot product of the row of matrix and the column of matrix (i.e., multiply the elements of each row of the first matrix by the elements of each column in the second matrix and then calculate the sum of the products).

product_series <- function(n) {  # create a function with n as an argument
  result <- 1                    # create an empty variable to store the product result with 1 as an initial value
    for (i in 2:n) {             # set for loop to iterate from 2 to n
    result <- result * (i+1)     # multiply the value of i+1 by the result variable
  }
  return(result)                 # return the final value of result
}

  • Factorization is the breaking down of a complex mathematical expression into a product of simpler terms known as factors.
  • The product of these factors, when multiplied, is equal to the original expression.

    • The highest power () in the polynomial is known as the degree of the polynomial.

    • Based on the degree, the polynomial can be classified as:

      • Cubic polynomial, if the degree is three.
